reviewText: Man, how in the world did the director/writers/producers take a phenomenal concept and just completely ruin it. This is one of those movies that deserves to be re-made by someone up to the task. The idea, the premise, is just that good.It starts out fantastic and then 20 minutes in you begin to see the shallow nature.. then by the end you just have your head in your hands going 'why, why, why would you go this direction!?'I'm sure most of you know the plot.. one night a year, American's get to completely purge their souls of evil by going on a criminal binge. All things are legal, chaos erupts in the streets, no police, no firemen, no hospitals, all of the systems put in place to protect you on a daily basis are gone. And anyone and everyone who wants to take a shot at you has an opportunity to do so - and there isn't a damn thing you can do about it except fight back.So, with a very horrifying concept in hand, what do we get? We get to see a bunch of rich people fight other rich people inside a house. Yea. A massive, nation-wide concept of horror and chaos... we get to experience it condensed into one house. One family. A wealthy family, who can afford protection, who would have undergone ZERO risk except for their own ignorance, find themselves embroiled in a Keeping up with the Jones' style mess. Basically we get an overly dramatic version of Panic Room... Panic Room may have been better.Now, I know some of your artsy types are going to talk about the expression of morals, or the juxtaposition of classes or the ironic motif etc. Blah, blah. Who cares. The point is this. It was an absolutely fantastic concept, truly one I looked forward to seeing. It was marketed correctly, the opening scenes set it up correctly, and then someone suffered brain damage and ruined the rest.I only gave two stars for the idea behind the movie, but I assure you there is very little worth seeing here. If you are a scary movie buff, I'd say watch it just so you can use it as an example as what not to do with a film.
summary: A great premise, just absolutely ruined in execution.

reviewText: THE PURGE (2012) poses an interesting, wild premise: What if, for a 12-hour period, one had the freedom to commit ANY crime?! That is the story in this unique, provocative, yet flawed film. This movie has gotten a lot of negative reviews, but I'm somewhere in the middle. While it has a few annoyances and frustrating moments, it does a good job of showing who your REAL friends are in this world and when the chips are down, who you perhaps can really count on. The "kindness of strangers" takes on a whole new meaning in this one!Set in the supposedly not-too-distant future, Hawke persuasively plays James Sandin, a rich suburbanite whose company sells "foolproof" home security systems designed to protect "the haves" against intruders during the annual purge, where the government allows anarchy to prevail for a period of 12 hours. Rampant crime is allowed and no one will be prosecuted as long as they commit their lawless acts within the acceptable timeframe. Sandin and his wife Mary (superbly played by Lena Headey), along with their 2 kids Charlie (Max Burkholder) and Zoey (Adelaide Kane) stay barricaded in their high-tech home, protected by the security system. But things go awry as Charlie spots a bloodied "Stranger" (excellently played by Edwin Hodge) running for his life, and activate the system to let him in. There is another major development (which kind of took me out of the movie for a while) that coincides with this. Then the group of psychotic purgers arrive to bargain with the Sandins to turn over the Stranger.There are several weak points of the film, most notably the actors playing the Sandin kids. I get that child actors should be allowed some leeway, but they were important to the plot. Also, these 2 characters did extremely frustrating things that caused all the trouble to begin with! Also, that early major development that coincides with the Stranger's arrival was one of the most convoluted things I've ever seen in a movie! I thought it was a cheap way for the director to get across the message, when the latter stages of the film did a more potent job of doing so. Finally, I thought the main purger tormenting the family wasn't very intimidating. A very standard stone-faced, monotone-speaking "movie psycho" character.Strong performances by Hawke, Headey, and Hodge help keep the film afloat, though. And the ending of the movie kind of helps save it to some degree, as it is very powerful and surprisingly non-cliche. Recommended with some caution!

reviewText: I do!  I believing in doing good things!  Good things that help people!  The Purge shows viewers the impossible law passing that allows 12 straight hours of committing crimes exactly one day out of the year.  It's legal!  Now at first I wasn't sure what kind of crimes the movie was going for.  I figured it meant petty things such as robbing a cashier man at the downtown convenience store or stealing food in a grocery store.  No!  This is a supposed law being passed that allows murder and rape!  What, really?  COME ON!Now of course, you can imagine due to the many low ratings here on amazon, many people dislike the concept and question its basis on reality.  No, it's not realistic at all.  I personally think the biggest crime this movie committed is calling itself a horror movie.  It's not really horror in the sense that ghosts and aliens torture people out of their homes.  That doesn't happen.  It's definitely more suspenseful than anything.Let me mention the flaws, of which there's many (and you probably knew I was going to mention them since it's unavoidable not to notice, hehe).- Why did it seem like hours before the scheduled purging got underway, the rich suburban neighborhood didn't seem to feel nervous in any way?  Regardless how well protected you are with firearms and regardless how modern and sturdy your installed security system is, wouldn't you at least be *somewhat* nervous?  Wouldn't you show at least a little concern?  We're talking about the strong possibility of death here or at the very least property destruction of some kind, and the family the movie in this movie has a younger son and a teenage daughter.  Isn't it human nature to be scared to death and DREAD this day?  Wouldn't you want to be extra cautious with your kids?  But... these parents didn't seem to care.  It's apparently just another walk down the sidewalk with Beaver and Wally in this neighborhood.- Let's say those willing to commit murder give in to their sadistic ways since they have a 12-hour window to do so.  Without releasing spoilers, what would stop a man from killing someone a few minutes after the 12 hours are up?  Especially if you go through the kind of torment this family does and murder almost seems necessary to survive.  It's not like the FBI and cops would be able to notice that you committed a crime by only a few minutes after the times up!  Then again if such a law is passed that allows murder, the cops and FBI are probably not too concerned about the day after anyway since it's too much law-breaking to handle at once.- Why did the family NOT stay in their protected firearm-loaded room the entire time the purge was occurring?  The daughter gets up and leaves because hanging out with her parents is apparently lame... and the son does too... and the parents do nothing to stop them!  I'd be like "Where do you think you two are going?  Get back here and sit with your mother and me for 12 hours while we wait and watch the camera filming the outside front yard!"  Hey, they could even make it a family night.  It's not like America has any of those anymore anyway.  :)With all that said, as a movie -a suspense- I'm willing to overlook the obvious flaws and the silly premise and just enjoy it.  While it does bring up a noticeable but never directly stated point that moral issues seem to be tossed aside these days just for the purpose of passing another law, I'd like to think America would *never* go down the path of allowing murders to happen one day out of the year for 12 hours.  This would be the worst possible thing ever, and anybody with a conscience should immediately realize how ridiculous this would be if true.The fictional storyline itself is just outrageous with MANY twists and turns.  In fact I'm only going to reveal one part, and that's when the younger son is watching the camera footage of his front yard on a TV in his backroom showing a man running, screaming and begging for someone to open the doors and let him inside.  He's begging for his life because a gang of highly unusual murder-happy young adults wearing masks and carrying guns are determined to take advantage of the purging (and basically worship this day) so they are going around targeting homeless people, which this man happens to be.The boy (played by Max Burkholder from the awesome drama Parenthood) lets him inside believing the man's really running for his life... and right after this all sorts of chaos ensues when the gang realizes the family is hiding the homeless man inside their tightly locked home, BUT... I consider none of the events that take place from here on out predictable for storyline purposes.  At least two MAJOR twists happen, maybe even three.  People you think are the bad guys suddenly turn good in the heat of the moment and vice versa, and the deaths themselves happen to be incredibly graphic.  The mother reluctantly holding a firearm as she roams the dark hallways assuming that nothing would go wrong is a good moment (or perhaps this is all unintentional and she's actually acting poorly in her role- ha, I hope not- would make me look like a big fool for complimenting her!)The story mostly focuses on the father wanting to protect his family from the gang of misfits that hang around their front yard and threaten to break into their home with back-up vehicles capable of destroying the security around the family's front door if they don't release the homeless man to them (who's now hiding somewhere in this dark, overlarge house and nobody knows where he is).  Here's the real kicker- the main guy from the gang happens to be exceptionally screwy in the head because to prove how serious he is about potentially murdering the family, he turns his gun to the man next to him who he claims is his best friend, and shoots/kills him.  Wow, even if the family WERE able to find and hand over the homeless man, would you seriously be willing to open the front door and take a chance that you won't eat a bullet for your troubles?  I certainly wouldn't trust the guy from that gang.  He just killed his friend!  He proved he's no more than a crazy lunatic himself.This movie is really crazy.  Thankfully we can all sleep easy knowing that such an annual purging ordeal would never really happen... right?  *waves tiny American flag and nervously sings God Bless America more convincingly than ever before* :)I know if I was in this situation I'd create a sturdy, well-protected backroom containing a variety of guns, much like the ones the family has in this movie that they mostly neglected to use, and I'd stay there wide awake the whole night shaking and waiting for anything unusual to come through that door... and then I'd react accordingly.  I'd only shoot if I felt my life was in danger.  Hopefully that's what most people would do because actually taking advantage of such a crime-filled night by going through with the committing of them should make you feel really bad and empty inside.  You're now soulless!I can't help but think there's many different ways to create a storyline out of a 12-hour crime spree.  Instead of creating a suburban rich family hiding and protecting themselves, they could have shown people with less money and resources scared for their lives in the main part of a city, and we could watch THEIR situations develop.  Or perhaps somewhere out in the country such as a farm in Kansas.  Or maybe Florida near Key West.  Or how about the snowy mountains of Alaska?  So many possibilities.At least the movie does several things right.  It's quality entertainment for one thing, and it's a storyline I've never encountered in a movie before so I feel it's somewhat original.  The parents -despite not feeling as much concern as they should concerning the safety of their children and their own safety thanks to the apparent confident belief that they're safe and sound in their suburban rich home- are good enough actors/actresses.  At least they're willing to die for their kids.  It's Max's character I like the most.  Him and his little remote control car with a red-eyed camera hidden inside turns out to be such a nifty, case-cracking tool!The ending has its problems though.  I mean now that it's all out in the open (*ahem!* I'm not spoiling what it is!) why take a chance and let it... fade away like nothing happened?  And return to normal after all that?  You can't.  You'd now be watching your back all day/everyday.  You have to finish it.  Finish it by packing your things, leaving and never coming back again.

reviewText: The basic premise of this movie could have been interesting....with better acting and a better storyline.  Instead, the movie is a thinly veiled vehicle for anti-white bigotry and propaganda.  You probably have some idea of the plot.  One night a year, law enforcement is suspended and anything goes.  The movie is pretty heavy handed in implying that people are universally evil but, limited to one night a year, they behave themselves the rest of the year.  There is some minor suggestion that this may have worked simply because Americans, enraged at all the crime, simply genocide the criminal element every year while law enforcement looks the other way.  In fact, the title, "The Purge" has a double meaning.  It is supposed to mean the cathartic purge of evil through one night of sheer wickedness a year.  But a purge could mean a selecting out and eliminating of a problematic element (and has been used that way multiple times in history).  Here is where the movie screws it up.  Those doing the purging are the very caricature of evil and the movie goes out of its way to portray white people, especially rich white people as either cowards who hide behind fortress walls or unreasonable psychopaths.  The victim is, of course black.  Since that is almost the exact opposite of how things are in real life, only this is like the millionth time today, some media has rammed that lie down my throat, the movie gets an F where its poor acting and tendency to drag would give it a D.  D minus, actually for the random scene where the girls boyfriend hides out in the home and attempts to murder her father for no particular reason whatsoever (because... you know....the way to impress a girl is by killing her family).  The magic black guy is, of course, a war hero.  And never mind the fact that black people refuse combat roles for the most part in every war ever waged.This movie could have not been a total wash if they simply eliminated the black guy as the victim and not went there.  It could, in fact, have been a great movie, if they made him a criminal scumbag, hiding out from the one night a year when law abiding folk are allowed to hunt him down like a dog in revenge.  Throw in a few surviving family of one of his victims.The movie has nowhere near the honesty, courage or even chutzpah to go there.  But it does far worse than play it safe.  It is a blatant attempt to lie about who is doing evil in our society.  In the end, it fails even at that.....being so heavy handed and unrealistic as to be unbelievable.....revealing its agenda and leaving an overall bad taste in the mouth.

reviewText: The writers and producers of the 2013 indie 'The Purge,' presumably having agreed already on a premise so childishly nonsensical (Cure for crime, unemployment, status anxiety, irritability and possibly moderate-to-severe eczema?  Duh.  Why, an annual day of legalized mass bloodletting, of course!  Oh, no you di'un't!  Oh, yes, we did!) I envision their original financing proposal involving box tops, chain letters and hamster-nappings-for-ransom, were so committed to their Burgessian vision of America's looming moral and socioeconomic demise they chose to double down on the implausibility factor of their dystopian masterwork by setting it a mere (then) nine years in the future.  (Mike Judge had the decency at least to contrive a 500-year buffer between us and his idiots' nightmare.)  Nine years?  I'm not crazy about my neighbors now-- how much will I hate them by '22?  I mean, I may not even have my Dr. Wayne Dyer self-improvement tapes paid off by then, which will only make me angrier... and poorer (PBS vampires!).  Suddenly I'm frightened.  Thanks a lot, 'Purge' people.  1 1/2 stars.Note:  all wisecracks aside, if you want to see an ultraviolent, twistedly entertaining rage-run-amok-in-civilized-society picture that doesn't require a believable premise, watch 2007's 'The Signal'; if you want to see a taut, scary home-invasion picture, watch 2006's 'Them' (aka 'Ils'); if you want to see a modestly violent, visionary socio-political satire set in the near future, watch Kubrick's 'A Clockwork Orange'; and if you want to see a ginormous octopus attack a cruise ship and eat everyone on it, watch 1998's 'Deep Rising.'

reviewText: In general, I hate movies that force the audience to completely suspend disbelief.  Naturally, this film would fall into that category.There's no way that this scenario would ever happen, and so that is its biggest problem.  But I still decided to give it a try, mostly because it was on "free" TV, but more so because I'm a fan of Ethan Hawke.  In particular, I was a big fan of his work -- and the film itself -- in "Gattaca," one of the best sci-fi films ever made.  That film was surprisingly believable, as it is quite possible that people in the future will be discriminated against due to genetics.  (It's probably happening already, what with sites like 23andMe.)  And I really liked "Sinister," a quite underrated horror film that really gives the audience the chills, even though the plot isn't exactly believable either.And I really hated it here how they overly moralized, what with the homeless black guy that the young-and-stupid-ultra-liberal son lets in.  Yikes.  Without giving too much away, I actually liked Mr. Hawkes original position, how he felt -- rightfully so -- that it was his job to protect his family at all costs; but then he later changes that position to probably appease a stupid American viewing audience.  I suppose the film makers wanted him to be a sympathetic character, and that's just a fail in this case.It is interesting to think about certain concepts:  NIMBY being one, since the protagonists originally didn't care about murders, as long as those murders happened outside the 'burbs.  And the idea that, if there weren't any laws, then there wouldn't be any crime.  (Yes, you don't have to think too long to realize that this is correct.  Ironically, laws create crime and criminals.)  But the film isn't strong enough to overcome its original weaknesses in believability.I'll go with a minor pass on this today, even though it's probably better than it should have been.

reviewText: I was excited to see this movie as I love thriller types like this. For the first half of the movie I genuinely enjoyed it. Maybe 4 star liked it. The idea of a Purge day and the process behind it was a twisted idea, but had great potential for movie of this sorts with many "What would you do?" type scenarios. He comes off as not understanding the horror/reason behind the purge - which is understandable. Heck, the adults were a little foggy on the concept. But we are left hanging as to whether or not he agrees/disagrees by the end - even though some of the movies major events circled around him. Maybe some people don't care about what he thinks. But seeing how he was the reason the stranger got in the house, he's the reason the stranger was protected, and he's the reason all hell broke loose at their house... I kinda think his "motive" is important!- What the hell happened to the stranger?!?! So in the beginning he is let in the house. Then through 75% of the movie he's in hiding. Okay. Cool, I guess. Whatever. Then out of nowhere at the end he just pops up and is like "Heeeeey - saved your life!" and becomes the hero. Seriously?- What the hell happened to the daughter?!?! Same thing as the stranger, she starts off as a major part in the movie. After her boyfriend goes batshit she just disappears somewhere in the house. reviewText: This movie got a lot of bad and lackluster reviews.  Honestly, what did people expect?  A nice walk through the park, perhaps?  Then obviously they were renting the wrong movie!Yes this movie is disturbing.  Yes it makes you angry and indignant and probably a bit grossed out and disgusted as well.  Isn't that why you want to watch it?  Be honest.In the movie, it is the year 2022.  Unemployment is at an all-time low of 1 percent.  Crime is way down as well - all in thanks to (according to the government) a yearly government sanctioned ritual called The Purge.  During The Purge, citizens are encouraged to "purge all their hostile and negative feelings" by committing any crime they want - EVEN MURDER - without ANY consequences.  There are NO POLICE...no fire department or medical services, either.  On March 22 of every year, for twelve hours, everyone is on their own.Enter our main characters, an upscale couple called The Sandins.  They live in a rich gated community with their two children.  The husband, James, sells home security systems for his career, and makes a lot of money doing this - naturally, due to The Purge.  Therefore, even though he's not really a BAD person, he does support The Purge (as all good citizens are encouraged to do) since this yearly bloody ritual makes him a boatload of money in his upscale neighborhood.Unfortunately, all of his neighbors are jealous of how well James is doing financially.After The Purge commences (there is a scary bull-horn sound and an announcement on the news) the Sandins high-tech security system whirs into action, creating a massive "lock-down."  The family assumes they are safe.  However, when the son peers outside on their expensive surveillance equipment, he sees that a bloody stranger has stumbled into their yard, crying and in need of help.  The kind-hearted boy lets this stranger into the Sandin's home - and after that, all hell breaks loose.A creepy menacing group soon descends upon the Sandin house, demanding the Sandins send the stranger out to them.  "He was our purge!" they claim, and they want him back...or ELSE, they will kill the whole Sandin family!What should the Sandins do?  Should they send this man back out and prove they have lost all humanity, such as others on this horrible night have done?  Or should they risk a deadly home invasion - and the lives of their own family members by not doing what the angry crowd demands?Now let me be perfectly clear:  This movie will never win any awards.  HOWEVER....if you are looking for plain old suspenseful entertainment....along with a desire to feel grateful that you do NOT live in that futuristic depiction of America - then watch the movie!  It will engage you, I promise.  I found myself talking back to the screen, feeling 100 percent THERE.The character development is adequate for this sort of movie, I think.  You do get a sense that this is a real suburban family.  There are characters you can route for - which I think is good - such as the son and the bloody stranger, who turns out to be a homeless man.I realized that The Purge seemed to mostly be about purging society of the poor.  This is indeed a very disturbing aspect of the movie.  Like I said before, though, the movie made me feel grateful for the world I live in now - a world that cares for and helps those in need.  This movie will definitely make you think about things like that!I think they could have done with out the overly sexy teenage daughter dressed in mini skirt, knee socks, and fake "school girl" outfit, looking like an anime character.  Or do they need to toss that sort of cliche into every horror movie to get young male viewers?All in all I feel The Purge delivered. Before I watched the movie, I was worried I wouldn't like any of the characters.  This thriller is definitely an action packed, edge of the seat ride.  Obviously, this movie should never be viewed by children!  Hopefully, everyone who watches the movie will be deeply appalled by the very idea of it.  If ever anyone thought The Purge was a GOOD idea, I would be very upset!So watch it - be entertained.  Maybe you want to rent or Pay per View as opposed to buying, though.
Title: The Purge

reviewText: A ridiculous premise may or may not deter people from venturing into "The Purge" and that may or may not be justified. A re-born American government has managed to eliminate crime, poverty and unemployment by allowing for one night, one 12-hour period a year, where there are no laws and no emergency services. For one night, murder, theft and whatever people of devious mind can think of, is legal. It is a simple premise and a silly premise. Although the creators of "The Purge", the movie, James DeManaco and Michael Bay, aren't necessarily trying to make an accurate statement, but a social one.The movie focuses on one family, the Sandin's; most noteably the father, James Sandin (Ethan Hawke). James is the man who marketed and sold the ultimate security system to all of the rich elite who can afford to be safe on a night like the Purge. Their homes are locked down and impenetrable, or are they? Well, if they were, we wouldn't have a movie now would we?"The Purge" has its moments of silliness; most of that in the final third of the movie. I have to admit that I was hooked though, for a bit. The tension builds nicely and you get to know the family enough that you care for them and their situation. The movie also tries to make a social statement about the Government and how people all have pent up anger and violent tendencies. Allowed to release that pent up and inevitable tendency for a short period, in theory, opens the door for 364 days of non-violence.The movie focuses its attention narrowly, which damages this attempt to make a wide government statement. The social statement works to an extent, although much of the finality of the film is spoiled by some silly staged moments, like people praying around their innocent and unarmed targets before doing the violent deed. Of course, anytime you see someone explaining what he or she is doing or pausing before doing something, it is almost always a lame setup for someone to interfere or spoil the plan.If you are going into "The Purge" expecting to see this premise explain itself or justify itself, save your money.  It isn't going to do it and you will inevitably come out thinking that the movie was as stupid as you assume it is.  The moviemakers aren't trying to justify this premise as something that is feasible; they are making a social comment in a fictional world. If you study the intent behind the characters actions given this one night opportunity, you will enjoy the movie much more.Regardless of which audience member you are though, the ending will inevitably leave you disappointed. The carnage and unpredictability takes a dramatic u-turn in the movies final third, becoming cliché' and safe. It built and built and then leveled off to a typical Hollywood, test-audience ruined dud. They could have done so much more to make people forget the premise and enjoy the film and they didn't.
summary: 2/3 OF A FILM DONE PROPERLY... unfortunately the other 1/3 was the ENDING

reviewText: Laughable in excess and poorly executed, the 2013 horror film "The Purge" is still an interesting take on the most terrifying of occurrences -- the home invasion crime. Such atrocities have been detailed in far more disturbing works including Michael Haneke'sFunny Games, Stanley Kubrick'sA Clockwork Orange(likely the great inspiration for this film) and Sam Peckinpah'sStraw Dogs (Unrated Version). Writer and director James DeMonaco has a good idea, but his film soars off the rails during the frantic second half. It could have been so much more.In the year 2022, the United States is amazingly crime free thanks to an annual event known as "The Purge," a demented Halloween rendering Shirley Jackson'sThe Lotterya low-key picnic. It is the one night of the year when residents can commit any crime they wish including murder, with the nation's police taking the evening off. Such a holiday allows American residents to vent their rage without fear of incarceration.James Sandin (Ethan Hawke) has made a comfortable living selling home security systems protecting well-to-do families from purge criminals. He pulls up to his beautiful home, the kind of picturesque structure one would see next to the par-5 at a country club, and has dinner with his attractive family, including wife Mary (Lena Headey) and his two truculent teenagers (Adelaide Kane, Max Burkholder).Naturally, the Sandin's home has the state-of-the-art security system. As the purge alarm sounds, a sort of tornado warning siren, James presses a button and huge metal doors slide down to cover the structure. With security cameras surrounding the house, the Sandin family kicks back to watch the "fun." At this point, the film loses it.DeMonaco has assembled a terrific cast for the family, and each actor gives an earnest performance. Hawke especially has evolved into one of the best actors working today. Perhaps not destined for superstar status, his fine work raises "The Purge" several notches, akin to his great performance in the recent horror classicSinister.I don't have a problem with events ratcheting up the suspense, including an injured African-American man (Edwin Hodge) who runs into the neighborhood begging for help. He's being chased by a fiendish gang of Caucasian college students adorned in costumes, masks and machetes. You see, the dirty secret of the purge is low-income residents cannot afford security systems, and thus are the main targets during the night of murder -- a sort of final solution conveniently cleansing the land of poverty.This thrill-kill cult is led by an unblinking, sadistic ring leader (Rhys Wakefield) with all the subtlety of Charles Manson -- a character so over the top he capsizes the entire film. For multiple reasons, they surround the Sandin's home and prepare to break in, leading to the film's best scene when Hawke's James admits his security system is not foolproof, serving more as a deterrent.The film enters the neighborhood of dull routine as every person with a gun can fire with deadly expertise, and the method the cult breaks in is akin to Tonto pulling down jail bars with nothing more than a horse and rope. For reasons not entirely clear, the family is separated throughout the spatial house with hallways as endless as Kane's Xanadu.Less is more with material like this, but DeMonaco does not trust his audience. If you're going to film an analogy exposing a flawed society consumed with repressed violence, don't embrace the mayhem for box office appeal. He's created some interesting characters. Why force them into implausibility and derivative shoot-outs?

reviewText: The Purge has an intriguing concept. The crime rate and unemployment are at an all time low and every year, America sections off one 12-hour interval known as 'The Purge' in which every law is temporarily suspended. In one very short segment, we are told that besides 'the purge' being an excuse for Americans to seriously indulge themselves, it also results in the deaths of many homeless people who are seen as drains on America's economy. Unfortunately, besides the interesting premise, The Purge is an utterly unimaginative and ridiculous home invasion movie. Its biggest misstep is failing to go deeper into the political themes, which are almost unbelievably shallow. Every time the film tricks the audience into thinking it might actually have something important to say, it takes a step back and someone gets offed in the most predictable way imaginable. The acting and directing are equally uninspired. Such a shame. It's very possible that if it had been more fleshed out and it was directed by someone with a dark visual flair (David Fincher), or maybe a sense of humor (Tim Burton), The Purge could have been something great.

reviewText: When I first saw the trailer for "The Purge," I thought:  that's an interesting (and actually new) idea for a movie.  The "purge" is the one night a year that EVERYTHING is legal:  murder, mayhem, torture--ANYTHING to let the good citizens of this country vent.  That is the first big problem I had:  the movie alluded that if you were rich, everything would be fine--you can BUY your safety.  Furthermore, it seemed the only people interested in the purge, were affluent snobs who (I guess) were bored and had nothing better to do.  It seems this has taken care of unemployment, capital crimes, and just about everything else.  That sounds interesting.  And then there's the movie.Written by James DeMonaco (who also directed), it seems he had no idea what to do with his movie.  There are many scenes that just make no sense.  I won't give any away; you will be able to spot them a mile away!  In fact, this movie is just all over the place.  Its writer and director never knew what he wanted to do with his characters.  There is little backstory.  The movie opens with Ethan Hawke driving home so he can lock down his house and wait until the purge is over.  He sells security systems for the very affluent and feels untouchable in his mansion.  Trouble is, he is VERY touchable.  Trouble starts when his son sees some helpless person trying to find solace before he is slaughtered, and he lets him into their home.  It's all downhill from there.  The final scene just had me shaking my head in disbelief.The movie is rated R for violence and language.  It stars Ethan Hawke (in a throwaway role) and Lena Headey, who should have stayed on the set of "Game of Thrones."  DeMonaco had a good idea for a movie.  Too bad he never thought everything through.  NOT RECOMMENDED.

reviewText: The premise behind writer/director James DeMonaco's film THE PURGE is indeed a fantastic one: set in the year 2022, when unemployment nationwide is down to just one percent, and crimes across the board are at an all-time low.  But what if the manner of getting it that was to allow a one-night "purge", in which violent behavior was actually sanctioned by the United States government, and largely to rid America of the poor and the indigent?  It is a premise that may seem outrageous; but so too was the idea of a surveillance state as depicted in George Orwell's classic 1948 novel "1984"; and what has America become since 9/11 but a real-life surveillance state?  Under the right circumstances, it is completely possible that something like THE PURGE might come to pass.Ethan Hawke portrays a security systems designer whose entire neighborhood, located in the hills above West Los Angeles, owes its very security and safety to his security designs.  It becomes especially important during a twelve-hour time frame from 7 PM to 7 AM on March 21st and 22nd, 2022 known as "The Purge", in which violent behavior, including murder, theft, and even rape, will be allowed--and no police or emergency first responders will be on duty.  It is a thing that Hawke and his family, and their neighbors, have gotten used to; and they have also become largely callous when it comes to the potential victims of the Purge, namely the poor who don't have the ability to support themselves with any job or pay approaching anywhere close to what Hawke makes.  But on this particular Purge Night, one of Hawke's children (Max Burkholder), out of the goodness and conscience of his heart, lets a wounded black man (Edwin Hodge) enter the premises, which upsets Hawke tremendously.  To Hawke, Hodge is exactly the kind of target the Purge people want to kill; and when the leader (Rhys Wakefield) of one such Purge group comes to get Hodge, Hawke, his family, and their home come under siege from that group.  Hawke at first advocates handing over Hodge to them (given that the Purge group has already totally crippled what Hawke had once proclaimed a foolproof security system), but his wife (Lena Headey), daughter (Adelaide Kane) and Burkholder, appalled at his descent into cold-blooded "survival of the fittest", force the issue.  In the end, they are forced to endure much physical horror and psychological terror until the morning comes.  And does the madness really even end there?DeMonaco wrote and directed THE PURGE on a budget of just slightly more than $3 million; and apart from the sometimes shaky and unsteady camera work (a trait that came from the quasi-documentary style of films like THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT and PARANORMAL ACTIVITY), every penny of that $3 million budget shows up here.  There are a number of things that don't quite work the way they should; and some of the acting, especially by Wakefield as the chief Purge instigator, is overly hammy.  In terms of what DeMonaco is basically trying to do with what is certainly a fantastic and crazy premise (one that seems to take a number of shots at right-wing elements of America, up to and including the Tea Party), however, THE PURGE is effective enough.  There is something extraordinarily ironic at rich, upscale people turning on one another, either for harboring a "filthy swine" such as Hodge, or for having their supposedly "foolproof" security system exposed.  In many ways, it derives its power and plot from many films: the original ASSAULT ON PRECINCT 13; A CLOCKWORK ORANGE (the masks worn by Wakefield and his posse); THE BIRDS; NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD; STRAW DOGS (the original 1971 Sam Peckinpah classic); and even THE OSTERMAN WEEKEND (Peckinpah's last, released in 1983).  But these are films that have a kinetic and psychological power that very few other "horror" or "thriller" films of this kind can have without spiraling into hyper-violent absurdity, and they are films that DeMonaco clearly has learned a lot from.Hawke does a fairly good job of being a somewhat callous capitalist who grossly underrates the impact that the violent behavior of the night of the Purge will have on his family.  Headey also does a credible job as his wife, who questions his motivations and his morality when, at first, he decides to hand Hodge over to Wakefield, instead of doing the right thing and fighting for his humanity.  In the final analysis, and in terms of its credibility and plausibility, it has to be said that THE PURGE isn't necessarily the best psychological "horror" or "thriller" film that has ever been.  But it is effective enough to deliver what it promises for its eighty-five minute running time.

reviewText: Films that make political statements aren't anything new, nor are they a revolutionary means of gaining otherwise unlikely attention.  Controversy has always been a means for creating revenue, especially in the United States where people tend to flock to scandalous news stories.  But, before you come after me for generalizing, hear me out.  The Purge, which is the subject of controversy due to comments made by James DeMonaco in relation to The Tea Party and NRA, appear to have stirred quite the commotion for a film that would typically never register on the average movie-goer's radar.  But, when roughly one-third of the United States is clearly conservative, attacking their base with a overbearingly apocalyptic film seems like a great way to aggravate that one-third, while still forcing them to go see the film in order to figure out what all the talk is about.  When you take that logic into account, mix it with a liberally-charged subject matter and the unremarkably high interest for blood-spillage from teenagers and young adults, you have quite the cocktail for success.The Purge, directed by James DeMonaco (Staten Island), stars Ethan Hawke as James Sandin, a home security developer that sells security systems to home owners in anticipation of a yearly 12-hour period, called "The Purge."  During the 12 hour window, the New Founding Fathers of America (government) allow Americans to "purge" themselves of crime, hate, and murder by legalizing these acts (with certain exceptions).  James Sandin and his wife, Mary (Lena Headey), along with their two kids, Zoey (Adelaide Kane) and Henry (Tony Oller), decide to stay in for "the purge," believing in its cause, but not partaking in the events.  However, the evening of The Purge takes a turn for the worst when Henry aids a bloody stranger (Edwin Hodge) begging for salvation outside the Sandin's residence.  The man's assailants, including the cryptic polite stranger (Rhys Wakefield), demand his release before they "purge" the entire Sandin family, too.  Arija Bareikis and Chris Mulkey also star in supporting roles.It's difficult to watch this film without focusing on the underlying themes that are completely in your face for its entirety.  The idiotic rational featured in this film states that America is better off if its citizens are given a 12 hour window to commit atrocities.  On the flip side, the government believes that if Americans are given this 12-hour window of "freedom," it alleviates crime and promotes job growth, along with economic prosperity for the remaining 364 days of the year.  Still, it's bothersome to think that people can simply go on a 12-hour crime/killing spree, and just go back to their regular lives the following day without any carry over.  They say once you've killed once, it's likely you'll do it again.  However, with that logic in mind, it's difficult to imagine any of these individuals would be able to wait a full year to kill or commit a crime again.  This film obviously gives the mind plenty to contemplate and it certainly creates a different way of thinking about the future direction of civilization.  Regardless, the film's premise is a complete and utter rip-off of the classic 1967 Star Trek episode, The Return of the Archons, in which an evil dictator rewards his minions with a similar 12-hour window to pillage and plunder an entire planet's civilians.Themes aside, there's very little about The Purge that separates itself from the array of unlawful entry films, not to mention the classic slasher films featuring Michael Myers or Jason Voorhees.  The abundance of stupid mistakes and clichés (like characters that still hide under the bed) really hurt this film, especially in the later half after the film turns into more a "so stupid it's funny" horror flick than a spine-tingling thriller.  For instance, if the son hadn't invited the random stranger into his house, the whole situation could have been avoided.  Of course, that wouldn't make for a very interesting movie - but it always takes something away from the film when the majority of viewers don't believe the situation is visible, especially in the horror genre.  For there, there's a series of irritating questions, like why are a large group of blood-thirsty individuals hell bent on "purging" spending so much time on won random bum/war veteran.  It makes the film feel like a whole lot of wasted time with very little reward.To be honest, the lack of star-power hasn't been a very big concern for the horror genre.  However, The Purge's leading man, Ethan Hawke, is far from an unrecognizable face.  Surprisingly, Hawke makes an enjoyable protagonist, but he just lacked the proper antagonist in this film.  His nemesis for the film, credited as the "polite stranger" is reminiscent of a watered-down version of Heath Ledger's joker persona.  If the joker were 15 years younger and starring in a CW version of Batman, he may have resembled the performance of the relatively unknown Rhys Wakefield.  And, to be honest, the kid (Henry) is rather creepy in the film, even though he turns out to be utterly harmless.  Tony Oller's portrayal is commendable, and even though he had the look of a future Michael Myers follower, (small spoiler) he turns out to be the voice of reason in the family's darkest hour.Overall, The Purge is a silly movie filled with a ton of potshots at America.  The film is chalk full of liberal bias, but is it anti-American?  Well, that's a matter of personal opinion, but the fact that a film like this can be made (even if the director is using his own personal criticism) means the First Amendment is alive and well.  The premise of this film is intriguing, although the execution is comical.  This is a difficult film to recommend, but it squeaks through mostly due to the high amount of enjoyment it provides should you be lucky enough to see it with a large group of people.  Due to the highly successful opening weekend, The Purge will no doubt have a sequel on the way.  Odds are on summer 2014.Overall Grade:  C-FNDNreview.com

reviewText: (Some spoilers follow)What if scenarios are great aren't they? One what if scenario that is an interesting topic of discussion is what if violence was allowed to take place without any repercussions?"The Purge" takes that topic and we see the consequences. Ethan Hawke plays James Sandin, a man who essentially gets paid for selling security systems. He of course has his own top notch security system in place. Lena Headey plays his peaceful housewife Mary while Adelaide Kane and Max Burkholder play the kids.The topic of what would happen if one day a state took the day off from regulating laws, and lets  its people become as violent as they want to be is an interesting topic for sure.  Of course, we know the consequences would be disastrous.  Without laws governing our behavior, a lot of people's fantasies and urges would take a deadly turn.  The movie does a pretty good job of showing that side of the story.In the beginning, Sandin and his family are pretty supportive of the process (as long as long they don't have to get their own hands dirty, and it doesn't affect them who cares right?) Then when they become the victims of the very thing they support they do a complete 360. What a surprise huh? (sarcasm)However, director  James Demonaco doesn't stop the theme of the movie to be just about the consequences of a lawless society, no he throws a lot of other themes in there. For instance, underneath the whole attack on the Sandin family for harboring a homeless man there is a subtext here for class warfare and prejudice.  The "purgers" keep referring to the homeless man as a "homeless pig" someone whose essentially (in their eyes)an undesirable entity that must be rubbed out just because he is not part of the rich elite class that James Sandin represents.I liked the character development though there could have been a bit more. Sure the Sandins are only concerned for the well being once the violence erupts, but they have their moment of enlightenment, and we all know that things will change from then on.Of course the movie isn't perfect and has a few flaws , but overall it's pretty entertaining. Again, imo puts out the themes out there without being overly preachy.

reviewText: I remember when the trailer to THE PURGE first came out and the premise was laid out, my good friend Bollywood Bob blurted out: "You mean I could jaywalk all night long and I WON'T GET A TICKET?!" Yes, Bollywood Bob, that's exactly right. During the Purge, you can jaywalk with immunity.In the year 2022 it's good to be a merchant of home security systems. In 2022 America is experiencing a remarkable era of peace and prosperity. Unemployment stands at 1%. Crime is at an unprecedented low. There's barely a whiff of Violence... except on one scheduled night, when the hooligans and the freaks and the mass murderers come out like sharks circling the water.March 21, 2022, and sucks for you if you lose track of time. When it strikes 7 o'clock in the evening, you had best be hunkered down in a safe place. Or you'd best be packin'. In this near future, the United States' new founding fathers have instituted the Purge, an annual twelve-hour period in which any crime is legal (and encouraged) and all emergency services are suspended. The working theory is that this state of anarchy serves as a psychological release valve. It's the one night that allows the populace to unleash its pent-up aggression. The movie's premise begs incredulity, but you can't deny its intrigue. And, yeah, it's a fairly novel concept. Note that a STAR TREK episode - "Return of the Archons" - did it first and four decades ago.3 out of 5 stars for THE PURGE, a film that is half social allegory, half home-invasion thriller. With its nifty hook and its (mostly) good cast, it should've been better than it was. Instead, there are any number of superior home invasion thrillers out there (THE STRANGERS, FUNNY GAMES, PANIC ROOM, WAIT UNTIL DARK). Mostly, THE PURGE is sabotaged by weak execution and by director James DeMonaco's pulling his punches. The result is a tour de blah down the cliché factory. Lots of fumbling in the dark. Some anemic scares. Sorry, hopeful gorehound.On the good side, the social satire comes across as sharply here as it does in, say, THE HUNGER GAMES. It's a premise that provokes thought and triggers some interesting discussions. I like that Ethan Hawke's character, James Sandin, who hawks home security systems, comes off as vaguely scumbaggish. Sandin is a man of his time. As such, he reacts with ingrained apathy and with reflex rationalization towards the atrocities committed during the Purge. It's been drummed into him that the Purge is good for the country. It unburdens the economy, never mind that it achieves this by eradicating the poor, the needy, the defenseless, and whoever else that doesn't contribute to society. His wife Mary (Lena Headey) is equally indifferent. It's hard to rage against something that's made you so rich. James Sandin, who is good at his job, has sold his security system to practically everyone in his affluent, gated community. He decorates his home with blue flowers as a show of support for the Purge. Leave it to their kids to conjure up the elephant in the room - Are they doing the right thing? To which one parent remarks: "Just remember all the good the Purge does, okay? That's all that matters."Me, I have trouble getting behind horror flicks in which the protagonists usher in their own doom, so there's that. I don't think I'm spoilering things when I say that, yeah, the intruders breach the Sandin household. But did you - as I did - yell at the kid when he did what he did? And did you then check yourself? Because what the kid did was stupid, yes, but he did it from a goodhearted place.Can this family under siege survive the night without forfeiting their humanity? More importantly, can you stomach this family? Will you find them likable enough to have a rooting interest? Ethan Hawke and Lena Headey deliver steady performances. It doesn't mean their characters are ones that you'd invite over. Or do you chafe under the collar because they're direct reflections of yourself if presented with the same harrowing choices? And I have to say it: The children are super annoying. The eccentric son, Charlie (Max Burkholder), is tapped as the one who asks the hard questions, so there's something to that. But, otherwise, he's such a damp, poorly etched character. The other kid, Zoey (Adelaide Kane), wastes copious screen time either being mopey or stupidly running away or in a state of catatonia. Turns out, the most likable person is the homeless guy (Edwin Hodge). The most interesting person would have to be Rhys Wakefield's creepy but very polite leader of a group of entitled psychopaths.Quick aside: Doesn't the boy's tricked-out, remote controlled toy tank with the ruined baby doll on top cry out "Hey, contrived plot device over here!" to you?A SPOILERS alert for this paragraph: For all the good acting work Ethan Hawke puts in, my favorite moment is the pool room scene in which he lets loose and unleashes his inner Straw Dog on a bunch of masked intruders. It's probably the film's highlight action sequence. Hawke does one thing here that is really gratifying. He puts down the intruders and then administers the finishing shots. How often does the good guy not finish off his opponent only to have the creep come back as a last-minute scare?THE PURGE raked in around $89 million on a $3 million budget. So of course there'll be a sequel and it's almost here. But will it dive as deeply into morality plays and class divides? Me, I'd be cool with a prequel in which we learn more about those game-changing founding fathers and we see what went down during the inaugural Purge.Just the other day my good friend Bollywood Bob crashed over at my place, and I heard him muttering in his sleep, something about the Purge and the need to "violate, annihilate, and cleanse our souls." I need to scrounge around for some blue flowers. Or a machete.The DVD's bonus stuff:- "Surviving the Night: The Making of The Purge" featurette (00:08:54 minutes long)

reviewText: If you enjoyed this review, make sure to check out my blog @ brandoncsites.blogspot.comThe Purge (2013) **D: James DeMonacoC: Ethan Hawke, Lena Headey, Max Burkholder, Adelaide Kane, Edwin Hodge, Rhys Wakefield, Tony Oller, Arija BareikisP: In 2022, under a nation reborn, with crime & unemployment at an all time low, an annual purge is held in which it is legal to commit any and all crimes, including murder.On one hand, The Purge is thought provoking and the type of film that will get people talking. Would you participate in the purge? What kind of activities would you or those that you know of engage in during a purge? What would we do for safety if you decided to stay in? Would you band up with your neighbors? Could you even trust your neighbors?The idea that in trying to be above it all, the film's protagonist becomes savages in of themselves by trying to protect their home is intriguing. There's also a surprising plot twist in the film's final act. Critics and audiences alike have debated about whether the film is able to fully take advantage of its ingenious concept. Whether The Purge fully took advantage of this idea isn't my issue with the film.My problem with The Purge is that the film mistakes sudden gun blasts for genuine suspense. My problem with The Purge is that their isn't enough teasing & taunting between the protagonist and the antagonist. If there was a purge occurring, if my home was being invaded, some of the emotions I would feel during that time would be fear, apprehension, tension, unease, confusion, disorientation, claustrophobia, etc. - emotions I never once felt while watching this film. That's definitely a problem. My problem with The Purge is that it lacks an understanding of how to craft suspense, terror and panic. Instead, melodrama involving the main characters takes the forefront distracting from the film's main event- The Purge.Writer / director James DeMonaco knows how to make a good story. He just doesn't know how to tell it, stage it or properly execute it. [R] 85 mins.

reviewText: The idea of the Purge is pretty original and neat. While it's not exactly practical it's an interesting idea that can touch upon a lot of different ideas like how far are you willing to go for the greater good and such. And while these questions were raised during the movie, the actual story was dumber than a bag of rocks. With all this potential, in all these different directions the story could've gone, it chooses home invasion. A pretty unremarkable one at that.Ethan Hawke and his family are rich and therefore have a home security system, so they lock themselves in and get ready to enjoy the night in comfy safety. However a bunch of things go wrong, and all of the potential suspense is quickly dissipated due to dumb decisions made by impulsive characters. The first thing that happens is the son sees a guy outside begging for help, so he unlocks the security and le-wait. Wait. How does the young son know the passcode to the security? Why would he know? *Sigh* buckle up because we're taking the Plothole Express to Stupidsville. So the son knows the passcode and lets the stranger into the house. Then a group of vigilantes come by and want the family to release the stranger so they can kill him.This is where it just gets worse. The message of morality is smacked in your face, and it's a flawed message at that. 'Even though this purge is helping America in the long run, how morally bankrupt have we become that we'll send an innocent man to the wolves?' That's what this movie tells you basically. But before we get all misty eyed and start applauding, let's think about a few things first. Would YOU risk your entire family's life for a total stranger? Your parents, your children, your brothers and sisters and husbands and wives, would you endanger them for a total stranger? Didn't think so. This stupid kid let the guy in, as far as I'm concerned the kid gets to be thrown out too for mindlessly risking his entire family's lives.So then they finally find the guy hiding in their house and they subdue him. Before they do however the stranger keeps going "I'm not gonna die tonight" and the family (except the stupid son) are like "get this guy outta here so we don't die", but after they're tying the guy to a chair to get him out, everyone but the dad gets cold feet and starts going "what have we become!?" while the stranger goes "let me die so your family can live". Yes, everyone starts flip-flopping their morality for no reason at all. Also when they're trying to present the guy, the dad, who suddenly forgot everything going on, decides to take forever with throwing the stranger out there, then changes his mind (but still leaves the stranger tied up). What's the point here, one family can't stand to watch someone pull the trigger?*Spoilers* So predictable mayhem ensues and the dad dies. Congratulations sonny, hope saving a random guy who you'll never see again was worth growing up a bastard for the rest of your life. I was hoping as the dad was dying he grabbed his son by the collar, got up to his face, and said "you.. did... this.." then dies, traumatizing that kid for life. Also the vigilantes outside consider themselves very intelligent people, yet for all their supposed intelligence they all completely spread apart and wander around the house by themselves, not being attracted to gunshots or fighting, or using their overwhelming numbers as an advantage. Same with the family, everyone splits apart, the kid is given a gun and a flashlight, and when dangers nearby, makes sure to shake his flashlight around because he wants everyone to know his location. The mom also wanders around her house the entire time with her arm completely stretched out holding a pistol. Because if someone's hiding in a room ready to attack, it's best to hold the gun as far away from you as possible. Then the neighbors hear the commotion and come to the rescue at the last minute, or so it seems. Instead they want to torture and kill the family, but not before reciting some stupid pointless ritual to drag out the scene, eventually getting saved by the stranger at the last minute(again). So what does the family do? They disarm their blood lusting neighbors and sit around with them awkwardly for the rest of the purge time. It's like all this crazy stuff happened and the only way to conclude it is by a scolding.This movie starts with an interesting concept, shrinks down to a little home invasion story, then starts slapping you with it's heavy handed message. The story is propelled along by stupid, illogical, and impulsive decisions. The only good that can come out of this movie is if they actually expand on the idea and show more society on a bigger scale instead of just one family. Other than that, screw this movie.

reviewText: When I first saw commercials for THE PURGE, it looked like every other home-invasion survival horror film that's been produced over the last several years; gleeful homicidal maniacs wearing creepy masks break into the home of a wealthy white-bread family, and the family has to fight them off. And with Ethan Hawke, one of the more overrated actors currently working, as the star, it had even less attractive qualities to me. But after reading about the concept behind the film, I decided to give writer/director James DeMonaco's film a try, because from a high-concept standpoint, THE PURGE sounded quite exciting.Well, the concept is still exciting, but the film doesn't get beyond the lowest-common-denominator garbage that it always looked like.In the United States of the not-too-distant future, poverty and crime are at all-time lows thanks to a group known as The New Founding Fathers (which we never see or hear about in specifics) who are now running the country. To offset the crippling economy and extreme criminality that had plagued the country just prior to the Fathers coming into power, they institute "The Purge", a 12-hour period of time where all crime, especially violent crime, is not only legal, but encouraged. At the heart of this film is the Sandin family (Hawke and Lena Headey as the parents, Adelaide Kane and Max Burkholder as the kids). James (Hawke) is a salesman of home security systems, and thanks to the Purge, he's become very successful. Mary (Headey) seems to be a stay-at-home mom, Zoey (Kane) is the mid-teen daughter seeing the older boy her father forbids her to see, and Charlie (Burkholder) is the tween son with a brain, playing with his remote-controlled tank/creepy doll-head. It's the day of the Purge, and they lock down their home for the night, but a homeless man (Edwin Hodge) outside is allowed in the home by the naive Charlie, and a pack of young preppy killers led by Rhys Wakefield (whose character credit is Polite Leader) demand that the Sandins release the "filthy homeless man" to their murderous urges, or they will smash down the barricades their house has and kill everyone. Morality and the protective urges are at conflict, but as you can predict, the preppies with their creepy masks and sing-song lunacy enter and the Sandins have to make a stand.Never mind that the second and third acts of the film play out almost exactly as you would think they would, aside from a moronic and telegraphed 11th-hour "twist". Never mind that everything that DeMonaco does with this film, from a visual standpoint, is totally uninspired and uninteresting. Never mind that the performances in the film are of the check-cashing variety, and that the members of the Sandin family are, naturally, morons in this situation. And never mind that James Sandin is a totally moral vacuum of a protagonist; how are we supposed to root for a man whose livelihood has been considerably improved by this event? If that was all the film was going to be, then it could have literally been recycled from dozens if not hundreds of the same type of film over the past several years. What really annoys me is the utter waste of a really powerful social, political and economic commentary that this film all but squanders by focusing on just this one incident with these specific people. If DeMonaco, who also wrote the abysmal remake of John Carpenter's ASSAULT ON PRECINCT 13 as well as the totally unwatchable werewolf horror-romance, SKINWALKERS, decided to focus more on building a world that these characters inhabit rather than just going to the cheap adrenaline rush of the home-invasion thriller, he might have had something really special. For instance, poverty and homelessness are potentially at such a low rate because it's the homeless and poor people that are being murdered on the night of The Purge. Where are the objectors to this idea? There can be no level of economic calamity and criminal brutality that would be so hopeless that everyone across America believes that The Purge is the solution. Who are the New Founding Fathers? What is their agenda? Is America a totalitarian state now? None of these ideas are explored in this film, other than the question of the homeless people, which is given nothing more than a perfunctory explanation.So, bad performances, bad script, bad direction all surrounded by a great idea makes THE PURGE an even more painful viewing experience. There's a very interesting film trapped somewhere in THE PURGE, but it's unlikely we'll ever see it.

reviewText: ****** No Plot Spoilers *******It is the year 2022.  A law has been passed which implements the Purge.  For one day only, from 7:00 P.M. to 7:00 A.M., all violent crime, including murder, is legal.  (Politicians, of course, are exempt; they always are from radical laws.)  James Sandin (Ethan Hawke, "Sinister") has become rich selling high tech home security systems to his neighbors.  He and his wife, Mary (Lena Headey, "Laid to Rest"), support the Purge; their children, ironically, question its morality, especially the youngest child, their precocious, nerdy son, Charlie [Max Burkholder, "Children of the Corn" (2009)].  This year, the Sandins are plunged into a twelve hour nightmare of blood and betrayal when a homeless war vet---pursued by a group of murderous yuppies---seeks refuge inside their mansion.James DeMonaco's "The Purge" is a clever morality play that reminded me of an episode of "The Twilight Zone."  I had to watch this provocative thriller twice before penning my review.  My girlfriend, Tammy, who gave it to me as an early Halloween present, was pleasantly surprised by my fascination with it.  She and I watched the film together and thoroughly enjoyed it for its gruesome violence, unsuspecting twists, and thought-provoking commentary on our country's violent culture where capital punishment, euthanasia, and abortion are legal.  Many of us, including myself, are not concerned about these highly controversial issues as long as they don't harm us.  However, our moral values quickly change when we are the victims.  The Sandin family rethinks their support of the controversial Purge when they become the targets in lieu of the homeless, the poor, and the unwanted who are the intended targets.At first glance, potential viewers would think that the Purge would never happen in this country.  We are too civilized for that.  Millions thought abortion would never be legalized.  Who would have thought Hitler would sanction the murder of over six million Jews?  What kind of culture brought the Nazi Regime into existence?  In "The Purge," the "freaks" who attack the Sandins wear masks.  Many of us wear masks throughout our lives.  We smile on the outside while hate, envy, bitterness and other sins eat away at us from the inside.  There are other methods of purging ourselves of these feeling without committing violent acts.  This is what distinguishes us from the animals--our ability to make choices.  On Purge night, we revert to our basic animal nature.  If given the opportunity, how many of us would participate in the Purge?  Everyone has that neighbor, coworker, or relative they have fantasized about killing.  For one night a year, the Purge allows us to turn our fantasies of killing into horrid reality.The only bonus feature that the Blu-ray has, other than English subtitles and a widescreen presentation, is a "making of" featurette titled "Surviving the Night."  Approximately eight to nine minutes in length, it provides interesting commentary from various members of the cast and crew.  Basically, the actors describe the film's horrifying content and the director describes his intention of making it provocative.  [There are also movie trailers galore for recently released new and classic thrillers from Universal Studios such as "Contraband," starring Mark Wahlberg, and "Scarface" (Al Pacino)].  Overall, "The Purge" is a must see for fans of provocative, futuristic horror involving desperate societies whose morals have become twisted such as "Logan's Run" (Michael York) and "Soylent Green" (Charlton Heston).  Watch it with a group of friends and conduct a roundtable; it makes a great topic for discussion.Joseph B. Hoyos
summary: James DeMonaco's "The Purge" is a Frightening, Provocative Thriller that Reminded Me of "The Twilight Zone"!

reviewText: The opening scenes introduce us to a dystopian futuristic America in which we have overcome staggering recessions, unemployment and crime rates.  Everyone seems happy and at peace with the means that provide this thriving economy.So what do they have to thank?  The Purge.  The Purge is a 12-hour period during which all crime is legal and all police, medical and emergency services are suspended.  Radio and news casts bombard viewers with soma-popping Brave New World mantras about "unleashing the beast within" to "cleanse [or purge] our inherently violent nature."What's most interesting about this society is that The Purge is embraced by most everyone.  Sure, there are media debates on how The Purge "targets" the poor who can't afford to defend themselves, but even the wealthy--with their armored home security systems--socialize, talk about what they're doing during The Purge or "purge" together in hunting parties.All of the pro-Purge political views are presented through an upper class filter--more specifically, the pro-Purge mindset of James Sandin (Ethan Hawke; Sinister, Daybreakers), a home security system salesman who lives in a ritzy neighborhood full of fake, well-to-do smiling neighbors.  This year, instead of attending a party, James is spending a quiet purge with his wife Mary (Lena Headey; Game of Thrones, Dredd, The Cave, The Brothers Grimm), son Charlie (Max Burkholder) and daughter Zooey (Adelaide Kane).James' family is less embracing of The Purge than the rest of the neighborhood but, for fear of death, they abide by the social standard but do not themselves partake.  Catching more of our attention is James.  His security system sales are booming, he's boat shopping and he talks a big game about supporting The Purge but when he justifies its value or explains to his son why he has never felt the urge to purge there is more than a dash of a hesitation in his tone.Things begin to go wrong for the Sandins when Max sympathizes with an injured man.  He hears his cries for help on the surveillance system and disarms the security for long enough to let the man into the house for safety.  Shortly thereafter, a group of over-educated young adults led by polite stranger with an intensely striking sense of rich kid entitlement demand that the Sandins release the injured victim into their lethal care as a Purge tribute.  If the Sandins don't, the strangers threaten to penetrate the security system and kill everyone.  That's what you get from the preview and I won't give you any more except to say that things get interesting, intense, gory, fun (for violent film fans) and equal parts predictable and unpredictable.I thought all of the actors did a fine job.  Solid performances across the board!  Some may consider the polite stranger (Rhys Wakefield) to be pretty hammed up, but I thought his supervillainous, sociopathic and zealous mentality helped separate this strong film from the likes of The Strangers, which carried no social commentary or message whatsoever.  As extreme as the premise may seem in The Purge, I must admit that it got me thinking.  Not necessarily "agreeing," but thinking.I went into this movie excited because of the preview, but nervous as to how it would play out.  In the end I feel that all of my positive expectations were met and none of the bad came to fruition.  I was very pleased.
summary: An intense, surprisingly well-executed film depicting a dystopia built on a foundation of an economy-fueling organized mayhem

reviewText: By the year 2022 the US government, led by our New Founding Fathers, has managed to crawl its way out of a triple dip recession and record crime rates. Unemployment stands at 1%, and crime is at an all time low. With one exception. Once a year, on a date designated as The Purge, for twelve hours all crime is legal. Rape, murder, theft, the entire US has a free pass to do whatever they wish and suffer no repercussions for it. In a single day thousands are murdered and millions of dollars worth of property destroyed in order to give everyday American's an outlet to vent their rage, anger, and frustrations in the hope that they will "cleanse their souls" and not be tempted to commit crimes for the rest of the year.First of all let's put aside the fact that the premise at face value makes absolutely no sense. I'll let that slide, though I do feel it needs to be said. The premise is what it is, and as implausible as it is, I still thought it interesting enough to warrant a look. But even overlooking  this, the movie has some serious flaws that I felt wasted what could have been a very intelligent film. First of all, this film is produced by the same people who brought us great horror movies like the Paranormal Activity movies, Insidious and Sinister, and while I loved those movies this film should have been different. The premise screams suspense thriller, as instead of dealing with supernatural beings like in their previous films, the main baddies in this one are a bunch of teenagers in masks and an old homeless man. To put it simply, there is nothing even remotely scary about this movie, so the fact that they filmed it like a horror movie with the typical horror movie tropes, jump scares, loud music, etc  only served as a distraction both for the director and the audience from what should have been the main focus. These sort of things worked for Sinister and Insidious because of their supernatural elements, because the villains were invisible, evil forces that couldn't be talked to or reasoned with. This film doesn't have that. Instead we have some homeless guy wandering around an inexplicably enormous house for an hour while the idiot family that lives there stumbles around in the dark. Am I honestly supposed to be scared by this? The Purge is a thriller in a horror movies clothing, and ultimately in my opinion fails horribly at being either.But what about The Purge itself? Do we get to see the streets turn into battle grounds? Is there subtle yet engaging social commentary to go along with such an interesting premise? Sadly, no. I don't know what these producers deal is with filming well off families in big houses, but this story should have really been told from the POV of someone who is poor and, thus, unable to afford protection from the roaming bands of psychotic rich kids trying to kill them. This is what should have been the focus of the film, not some boring rich family with first world problems, but the poor and downtrodden who are the real victims of this sick tradition. Imagine a film where a poor, single mother/father flees with their children from bands of killers who are not only allowed to kill at will, but encouraged to do so as well. That would have been a great movie. Instead we get boring suburban dad with boring suburban wife, and boring suburban kids. Nothing gets my heart strings strumming like privileged rich people trying to throw some poor homeless guy to the wolves. Yeah, I feel real sorry for those guys.The Purge is a film that had a great idea but no idea how to see it through. Its boring, badly directed, and commits the cardinal sin of being a horror movie that isn't even remotely scary. If you really want to see it, wait until its on netflix and stream it. Otherwise, my suggestion is to pass. Its really not worth the effort.

reviewText: Let me start out by being perfectly clear. When I saw the first trailer for The Purge, I thought to myself, that is going to be a great horror movie. Just last year, 2012 to be exact, a movie called The Cabin In The Woods was released. I gotta say, Joss Whedon made two great movies last year: The Avengers, and The Cabin In The Woods. So naturally I read up the premise on The Purge, and almost immediately, Cabin In the Woods was the first movie that I could think of to sort of compare The Purge to. I just got finished watching The Purge. Is it great like I hoped? Sadly no it is not and on any other given Sunday, I would call this movie god awful. But there is something admirable and admittedly a little thought provoking about this movie that made me enjoy it.The Purge stars Ethan Hawke and Lena Headey as James and Mary Sandin. Another thing that sparked my interest with this movie was the two lead actors Ethan Hawke who already starred in another horror film Sinister, and Lena Headey from the brilliant show Game of Thrones and the movie 300. I would say the acting in this movie is not the best, but then again not very many horror movies are known for giving Oscar worthy performances. In the Purge, it is the year 2022 where on one specific night for 12 hours crime is legal. That's right CRIME. 12 hours may not seem like a very long time, but trust me IT IS. I would note that one of the pros this movie has is that the story, while it is predictable at times, does keep you guessing and keeps your attention for the entire movie.Now my problem with The Purge is this: for what the premise suggests and the rating it has, you would initially consider this to be an all out horror film. As a matter of fact, I would consider it more of psychiatric thriller or something of that nature. In my honest opinion, The Purge is not very scary at all. Be mindful, there is a lot of violence and chaos going on, but this is not a film that would scare you sleepless in my opinion. Another problem is that there are some things that don't make a whole lot of sense in the movie, but strangely enough, I was able to overlook it.After watching The Purge, I said to myself " I am supposed to dislike this movie'' "why in the world do i like this movie so much?'' To be perfectly honest, some might think I am in need of a brain exam for liking this movie. But I do admire the way The Purge tries to be creative and clever (although its not very clever). And I especially admired the overall tone of the movie. It is nowhere near perfect, The Purge is not, but as a movie, it gets3.5 stars
summary: Not quite Scary and not the most clever, but it does make you wonder.....
